In this case, the premise is "If the bear was in the case, then the wolf was in the den," and the conclusion is "If the wolf was in the den, then the bear was in the case." However, the fact that the wolf is in the den does not necessarily imply that the bear is in the case. There could be other reasons why the wolf is in the den, and the bear could be elsewhere. Therefore, this argument is not logically valid.
